This will be an open discussion meeting to discuss any topics brought up at meeting time. On the agenda at the moment are:

This meeting has been canceled. We'll try again in July.
This meeting has been cancelled.
Meeting cancelled, I think everyone is on vacation.

Our regular October meeting. 

This month there are no talks planned. We will meet to discuss the upcoming Python 3k (3.0) release. I will build this release on my laptop so we can play with it, and we can go over some of the changes and discuss them. 

This would also be a good time to go over Python 2.6.

[New features in Python 2.6](http://docs.python.org/whatsnew/2.6.html)

[New features in Python 3.0](http://docs.python.org/dev/3.0/whatsnew/3.0.html)
TBD
TBD

This meeting is canceled due to inclement weather and lack of material. 

Yes, I know. We're working on it.

Our monthly meeting for March, 2009.

Note, this is not our usual room, we had to change it for this meeting.

This meeting strays from our usual format, and location. We're planning to reserve a back room for our meeting, and do some friendly networking, plus some lightning talks. Note the location for this meeting, as opposed to Carleton U. The booking of the back room in the pub is free, but please plan to pay for it in pub fare. We're in the "big room". Look for the geeks. :)

fields.details: For our regular monthly meeting we have a variety of suggestions. Currently we have one confirmed talk from Ian with two tentative. I'll see if I can come up with something and if you want to join in, just let us know on the mailing list.

Our regular monthly meeting for May will be pushed back by one week due to a member conflict. We hope that's ok for everyone. The theme of this meeting is "extending Python in C/C++". See below for talk details.

I will give an overview of how the OPAG website was rebuilt to use [Django](http://www.djangoproject.com/).

I hope to cover:

- installation of Django (quickly)
- configuration for development inside an SCM system (I used [Mercurial](http://www.selenic.com/mercurial/wiki/))
- use different databases in development and deployment
- deployment with [mod_python](http://www.modpython.org/)
fields.name: Michael P. Soulier

fields.details: Andrew Francis will discuss how he used [Stackless Python](http://www.stackless.com/) and the [Twisted](http://twistedmatrix.com/) Network Framework in the construction of his Python-based [WS-BPEL](http://www.oasis-open.org/committees/wsbpel/) (Web Services - Business Process Execution Language) processor "Stagehand."
fields.name: Andrew Francis

fields.details:
At [Mitel](http://www.mitel.com/), I work full-time on a Linux server and its applications, the configuration of which is handled via a web interface. 

I am in the process of migrating the existing [Perl](http://www.perl.com/) framework to one using [Python](http://www.python.org/) and [Django](http://www.djangoproject.com/), and I plan to talk about the challenges I've had so far, and the solutions I've come up with, in having to push Django into a legacy environment such as this, as opposed to a brand new site.
fields.name: Michael P. Soulier

fields.details: I've developed a very small sketching application for a tablet PC.  The first prototype was grown using [wx](http://www.wxpython.org), the second and current prototype was re-written in [pygtk](http://www.pygtk.org).  In this talk I'll try to describe some of the differences I've noticed.
fields.name: Neal Holtz

fields.details:
From the [Scapy website](http://www.secdev.org/projects/scapy/):
Scapy is a powerful interactive packet manipulation program. It is able to forge or decode packets of a wide number of protocols, send them on the wire, capture them, match requests and replies, and much more.
Peter will give an overview of Scapy.
fields.name: Peter Shook

fields.details:
Peter will give an overview of the new features in Python 3.0.

   * [Metaclasses in Python 3000](http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3115/)
   * [Function Annotations](http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3107/)
   * [Extended Iterable Unpacking](http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3132/)  
   * [Advanced String Formatting](http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3101/)
   * [Class Decorators](http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3129/)
fields.name: Peter Shook

fields.details: While [Django](http://www.djangoproject.com/) is a wonderful framework for web applications, often back-end work must be done to keep those applications running. I will introduce some techniques that I am using to work with the Django models directly from back-end Python scripts to perform maintenance, and automate some tasks in my current project.
fields.name: Michael P. Soulier

fields.details:
While nothing special is required of any web framework to make use of AJAX-based features, Django is actually well-suited to supporting AJAX. While it won't write your code for you, thanks to frameworks like [Prototype](http://www.prototypejs.org/), it's really not difficult to make use of AJAX in a variety of ways. 

I will demonstrate some of what I've done so far in this respect.
fields.name: Michael P. Soulier

fields.details:
Having worked with Django in the front-end and the back-end, I ran into concurrency issues very quickly. I'll quickly go over how I solved them using PostgreSQL as the database, via transactions and locking.

It is an early solution, so your comments are welcome to help me improve it, as I am by no means a PostgreSQL expert.
fields.name: Michael Soulier

fields.details:
I've been using [Git](http://git-scm.com/) now for a while, and I am working on a talk internal to the company that I work for to introduce them to it. I'd like to try out the public parts of the talk on the OPAG group, and provide some comparisons to Mercurial, since I did introduce Hg a while back.

If there is a [Bazaar](http://bazaar-vcs.org/) expert about, I wouldn't mind some comparison there either.
fields.name: Michael Soulier

fields.details:
[Urwid](http://excess.org/urwid/) is a console user interface library for Python

Ian will talk about Urwid's new High colour support and new main event
loops including [Twisted](http://twistedmatrix.com) and [GTK](http://www.gtk.org/).
fields.name: Ian Ward

fields.details: See topic. :)
fields.name: Ian Ward

fields.details: Ian is going to tell us about what's coming in [Django 1.1](http://www.djangoproject.com/weblog/2009/may/07/django-1-1-update/) appearing on a mirror near you soon.
fields.name: Ian Ward

fields.details:
If you are using the standard database-backed session store, and are making use of transactions, there is an issue that you can run into in Django if you are managing your transactions manually.

I will outline and problem, and a few solutions, including the one I chose.
fields.name: Michael P. Soulier
fields.topic: Lightning talk: Manual transactions and session gotcha in Django

fields.details: Scott is going to enlighten us on [sphinx](http://sphinx.pocoo.org/), a Python documentation tool suite based on reStructured Text.
fields.name: Scott Lyons

fields.details:
I am going to give a quick overview of Python's 
[multiprocessing](http://www.python.org/doc/current/library/multiprocessing.html) module and how I am currently using it to provide a 
[Twisted](http://twistedmatrix.com/trac/)-based web service.
fields.name: Michael Soulier

fields.details:
Ian will give a short presentation and lead a discussion about building custom 
[Django](http://www.djangoproject.com/) forms with non-trivial validation code.  
[Formset](http://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.1/topics/forms/formsets/#topics-forms-formsets) usage will also be covered.
fields.name: Ian Ward

fields.details: Scott may be presenting a talk on extensions in C.
fields.name: Scott Lyons

fields.details: Andrzej might show up with some hardware for his home energy dashboard project.
fields.name: Andrzej Borowiec

fields.details: Brenda will present a short introduction to the [Byteflow](http://byteflow.su/) blogging software, which makes use of [Django](http://www.djangoproject.com/).
fields.name: Brenda Butler

fields.details:
Scott is going to share with us how to extend Python via C/C++.

We need Scott to confirm this but I believe he is going to begin with basic inclusion of Python.h, and then move up to more abstracted methods of extension, such as stub generation tools.

I could conceivably provide examples in Perl and Java for comparison, if required.
fields.name: Scott Lyon
